newsitem.title: HONG KONG: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Sterlite steps in.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - Sterlite steps in.

text.p: Indian cable-maker Sterlite Industries stepped into Asian debt markets on Thursday with its first-ever floating rate note launched into international markets.
The US$70 million notes mature in 2007 but can be put after seven years. They were launched at par to float at 130 basis points over the six-month London Interbank Offered Rate.
With fees, the all-in return is 138.57 basis points.
Union Bank of Switzerland is the lead manager.
Sterlite is one of a number of Indian companies planning to tap the capital markets.
UBS also has a mandate to arrange a US$100 million seven-year straight bond for Arvind Mills.
Indian Railway Finance Corp IRLY.BO has mandated ANZ to arrange a floating rate note issue.
Steel Authority of India has been talking with investment banks about a fixed-rate bond.
Indian issuers have attracted interest lately partly because the government has moved to relax some rules on offshore borrowings, bankers said.
Some syndicate managers in Hong Kong said the Sterlite deal was priced too tightly, comparing it with a recent issue by CESC, the Calcutta-based power utility.
CESC's issue, a 10-year deal which can be put or called after seven years, paid a coupon of 150 basis points over LIBOR and an all-in of roughly 157 basis points.
Bankers said there is renewed speculation that India may issue a sovereign bond later this year.
In other news, Thailand's Robinson Department Store launched a 6.8 billion yen floating rate note issue.
The three-year notes were priced at par to float at 135 basis points over the six-month yen London Interbank Offered Rate. With fees, the all-in return is 176.6 basis points.
Development Bank of Singapore and Societe Generale Asia are lead managers.
A number of issuers have opted for yen financing of late. Bankers said the yen deals are attractive because the withholding tax is lower than for dollar-based transactions.
Swapped into dollars, the Robinson Department Store deal pays about 180 basis points, a wider spread than the company offered a year ago.
Thai issuers have had to pay more for their money this year in the wake of Thailand's financial problems and its downgrading by Moody's Investors Service to A3 from A2.
Bankers said Associates Corp's first Euro-Asian floating rate note, which was priced on Wednesday in London, attracted good interest in Asia, although European accounts were the biggest buyers.
The five-year notes were priced to give a discount margin of 10 basis points over LIBOR, a level deemed generous.
Bankers said Guangdong Enterprises will start roadshowing its 144a Yankee bond imminently. The bond reportedly will be about US$250 million and have a maturity of 10 years.
Merrill Lynch is the lead manager, while HSBC Markets and CS First Boston are participating as co-lead managers.
